title: Boeing targets 2026 as early recovery year with positive free cash flow
summary: Boeing is projected to shift from a multi-year cash burn to sustainably positive free operating cash flow (FOCF) of approximately $3 billion in 2026. This turnaround is predicated on stabilizing the 737 production at 47 per month and liquidating legacy inventory.
talkingPoint: With 2026 projected as Boeing's first year of sustained positive cash flow, how are you evaluating your fleet renewal timelines to align with their production recovery?

title: Certification 'triple crown' of 737-7, 737-10, and 777-9 in 2026
summary: Boeing's strategic focus for 2026 is the certification of three major models: the MAX-7, MAX-10, and the initial 777-9. While the 777-9 first delivery has slipped to 2027, the certification process in 2026 is the critical path to restoring market trust and competing with Airbus in the large narrowbody and widebody segments.
talkingPoint: As Boeing moves toward certification for the MAX-10 and 777-9 in 2026, how much capacity planning are you doing around these specific high-capacity variants?

title: Acquisition and integration of Spirit AeroSystems to fix quality
summary: Boeing completed the $8.3 billion acquisition of Spirit AeroSystems in late 2025 to bring fuselage and structure manufacturing back in-house. The goal for 2026 is to eliminate 'traveled work' and out-of-sequence fixes that have historically caused quality lapses and production delays.
talkingPoint: With the reintegration of Spirit AeroSystems, Boeing is looking to gain tighter control over its supply chain quality. Is your organization considering similar vertical integration to mitigate third-party quality risks?

title: 737 production ramp-up to 47 per month by mid-2026
summary: Following FAA approval to reach 42 aircraft per month, Boeing plans to move to a rate of 47 per month in 2026. This ramp is being monitored through six key performance indicators (KPIs) to ensure production stability and avoid the quality issues that plagued previous years.
talkingPoint: Boeing's next production leap is to 47 narrowbodies per month. How will this increased availability impact your fleet competition and delivery slots relative to your competitors?

title: FAA oversight shifts from production halt to culture audit
summary: FAA oversight remains intense but has shifted toward auditing Boeing's safety culture and employee training following the 2024 production cap. 2026 performance will be judged on 'fundamental cultural shifts' rather than just unit volume.
talkingPoint: With regulators focusing on 'safety culture' as a leading indicator, how is your leadership team benchmarking your own safety management systems against these evolving FAA standards?

title: 787 production goal of 10 per month by end of 2026
summary: Boeing is systematically increasing 787 widebody production from seven to ten units per month by the end of 2026. This widebody strength remains a critical competitive moat for Boeing, particularly as Airbus faces its own engine supply challenges in the same segment.
talkingPoint: The 787 continues to be a strong widebody performer. Are you factoring in the 787's superior payload-to-range specs when planning your long-haul network expansion for 2027?

title: Boeing likely to reclaim jet-sales title from Airbus in 2026
summary: Market analysts predict Boeing could outsell Airbus in overall commercial aircraft orders in 2025-2026 for the first time this decade. This resurgence is driven by strong widebody demand and aggressive fleet renewal orders from major carriers like Alaska Air.
talkingPoint: Boeing is regaining sales momentum. Does this shift in the order race change how you negotiate long-term pricing or support contracts with the two major OEMs?

title: Global supply chain bottlenecks to cost industry $11B in 2025
summary: Aerospace supply chain constraints—particularly labor shortages and airframe-engine mismatch—are projected to create an $11 billion cost burden on airlines in 2025. Boeing's recovery depends heavily on its ability to help key suppliers stabilize their own production.
talkingPoint: With supply chain bottlenecks expected to persist into 2026, how are you hedging against 'gliders'—aircraft delivered without engines—affecting your service entry dates?

title: Shift toward 'Smart Factory' and AI-integrated manufacturing
summary: Boeing is undergoing a digital transformation to create a 'Smart Factory' ecosystem. This includes integrating AI for real-time contaminant detection, predictive maintenance, and machine learning to optimize the assembly of composite parts.
talkingPoint: Boeing is moving toward a 'Smart Factory' model to solve quality issues. How are you utilizing similar data-driven insights in your own MRO or operation cycles?

title: Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) commitment for 2030 fleet
summary: Boeing has committed to ensuring its entire fleet is capable of flying on 100% SAF by 2030. In 2024, it increased SAF blend purchases for its own operations by 60%, positioning itself as a leader in decarbonizing air travel.
talkingPoint: With Boeing targeting 100% SAF compatibility, what is your roadmap for transitioning your current fuel procurement strategy to take advantage of these technological gains?

title: 777X program delay results in $4.9B non-cash charge
summary: A major re-evaluation of the 777X certification timeline led to a $4.9 billion pre-tax charge in late 2025, pushing the first delivery of the 777-9 to 2027. This delay increases inventory build-up and is expected to create a $2 billion cash flow headwind in 2026.
talkingPoint: The 777X delay will create a $2B cash flow headwind in 2026. How are you adjusting your long-haul capacity forecasts given this new first-delivery date of 2027?

title: Global Services segment provides high-margin stability
summary: Boeing's Global Services (BGS) segment continues to show resilience, with 17.5% operating margins in late 2025. This high-margin business offsets losses in commercial airplane production as airlines extend the lifespans of legacy fleets due to new aircraft delays.
talkingPoint: As your fleet ages due to delivery delays, what strategies are you using to manage the rising costs of maintenance and repair for your mid-life aircraft?

title: FAA mandates repetitive inspections for 737 MAX structural cracks
summary: The FAA has proposed a new airworthiness directive for the 737 MAX family due to reports of cracks in the bear strap and stub frame at galley door cutouts. This requires repetitive, labor-intensive inspections that could disrupt regional airline schedules into 2026.
talkingPoint: With new mandatory inspections for the MAX, how are you planning your MRO schedules to minimize the impact of these additional structural checks on your daily operations?

title: Defense segment recovery focused on fixed-price contract risk
summary: Boeing is working to stabilize its Defense, Space & Security (BDS) segment, which recorded a 1.7% operating margin in late 2025 after years of losses on fixed-price development contracts. Future growth is underpinned by allied defense spending amid global tensions.
talkingPoint: Boeing is prioritizing stability in defense. How is your firm factoring in geopolitical stability and allied defense spending when forecasting your own industrial or logistic demand?

title: Impact of China's delivery pause on narrowbody momentum
summary: A recent pause in deliveries to China has added geopolitical complexity to Boeing's 737 MAX production recovery. Resolving these trade-related delays is essential for Boeing to hit its 2026 production and cash flow targets.
talkingPoint: Trade-related delivery pauses are impacting aircraft availability. How is your international network strategy accounting for the risk of geopolitical friction affecting your fleet procurement?
